IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: Timanous Foundation is dedicated to providing a camp life that builds character and has lasting value for every boy.
IRS990.MissionDesc: Timanous Foundation is dedicated to providing a camp life that builds character and has lasting value for every boy.
IRS990.Desc: Timanous Foundation was created to operate Camp Timanous, a boys' overnight summer camp located in Southern Maine. As a nonprofit organization, the Foundation is committed to ensuring that the camp remains loyal to its enduring and traditional ideals.The Foundation is dedicated to providing a camp life that builds character and has lasting value for every boy. This camp life features:- Simple, active living in a rustic environment- Deep respect for the rights and self-worth of every individual- Holistic growth of body, mind and spirit(Continued on Schedule O...)The Foundation supports this camp life by fostering high standards for counselors as role models and leaders; maintaining generational continuity of the camp community; and committing to expand our community to include more economically and demographically diverse populations.

Form990ScheduleAPartVIGrp.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Schedule A, Part II, Short Year Disclosure
Form990ScheduleAPartVIGrp.ExplanationTxt: On the Foundation's Schedule A, Part II, Public Support Test, the 2018 column represents a short tax year, when the Foundation changed its tax year-end from December 31 to August 31.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Foundation pays dues and membership fees to various professional associations designed to promote youth health and recreation. Some of these associations may allocate a portion their membership fees for lobbying expenditures. In its tax year ending August 31, 2022, the Foundation paid the Maine Youth Camp Association (MYCA) total dues of $1,044. The Foundation received notice from the MYCA that the amount of dues used by MYCA for lobbying purposes in 2022 was $26.
The Foundation's endowment is used to provide camperships to the camp for children of need.

The Foundation is exempt from federal and state income tax under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code. Accordingly, no provision for income taxes has been recorded in the financial statements. Tax-exempt organizations could be required to record an obligation for income taxes as the result of a tax position they have historically taken on various tax exposure items including unrelated business income or tax status. Under guidance issued by the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB), assets and liabilities are established for uncertain tax positions taken or positions expected to be taken in income tax returns when such positions are judged to not meet the "more-likely-than-not" threshold, based upon the technical merits of the position. The Foundation has evaluated the position taken on its filed tax returns. The Foundation has not taken, nor does it expect to take any uncertain tax positions in any income tax return.

Camp scholarships ("Camperships") are awarded to campers based on their financial need and merit. The Foundation consults with various educational institutions, schools, state programs, and youth and family service organizations to find deserving campers who are in need of financial assistance. The Foundation works with campers and their families to ensure that otherwise eligible campers receive the necessary financial assistance that is required to attend the summer camp programs. The Foundation accounts for "Camperships" (camp tuition scholarships), tuition discounts, and fee remissions net of its tuition revenues in its audited financial statements. The Foundation maintains records to document and track which campers receive financial aid and at what amount. The Foundation also maintains endowment funds to provide financial aid to deserving and eligible campers in need, and openly advertises that financial aid opportunities are available on its website.

Garth Altenburg, the Foundation's Director, is provided a cabin on-site at the camp through the camp-season. The responsibilities of Mr. Altenburg's position may require him to be available and of service at all times during the camping season. The provision of housing to camp staff and directors is considered standard practice within the summer camp industry. Under Section 119 of the Internal Revenue Code, lodging furnished to an employee is excluded from gross income if the lodging is (A) provided for the convenience of the employer; (B) provided on-premises of the business and close in proximity to the area of service; and (C), the employee is required to accept such lodging as a condition of employment. Garth Altenburg would not be able to perform the duties of his position were he not living on the Foundation's camp-grounds. Mr. Altenburg's housing is furnished through a cabin at the camp's primary location, and is a required condition of his employment with the Foundation. Accordingly, the housing meets the IRC Section 119 conditions for exclusion from income.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 2
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Two of the Foundation's trustees, David Suitor and Linda McGorrill Suitor, have a family relationship.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11b
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Form 990 is prepared by the organization's outside CPA firm and a draft is provided to each board member for review prior to filing.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: 1. Duty to Disclose: In connection with any actual or possible conflict of interest, an interested person must disclose the existence of the financial interest and all material facts to the board of trustees. 2. Determining Whether a Conflict of Interest Exists: After disclosure of the financial interest and all material facts, the disinterested members of the board of trustees outside of the presence of the interested person shall decide if a conflict of interest exists. 3. Procedures for Addressing the Conflict of Interest: a. An interested person may make a presentation about the transaction or arrangement in which he/she has a conflict of interest at the board of trustees meeting, but after the presentation, he/she shall leave the meeting during the discussion of, and the vote on, the transaction or arrangement involving a conflict of interest. b. When a conflict of interest has been determined, the chairperson of the board of directors shall, if appropriate, appoint a disinterested person or committee to investigate alternatives to the proposed transaction or arrangement. c. After exercising due diligence, the board of trustees shall determine whether the Foundation can obtain with reasonable efforts a more advantageous transaction or arrangement from a person or entity that would not give rise to a conflict of interest. d. If a more advantageous transaction or arrangement is not reasonably possible under circumstances not producing a conflict of interest, the board of trustees shall determine by a majority vote of the disinterested directors whether the transaction or arrangement is in the Foundation's best interest, for its own benefit, and whether it is fair and reasonable. In conformity with the above determination it shall make its decision as to whether to enter into the transaction or arrangement.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15a
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Director Altenburg's salary package was established after a review of comparable other positions in the Maine camping industry, and was approved by the Chairman and the Vice-Chairman of the board.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: These documents are available upon request.
The audit process has not changed from the previous year.
